briefOverview: A first-person divine account of the six creative days, highlighting creation by God through the Only Begotten and culminating in humanity’s creation in God’s image with a mandate to multiply and exercise dominion.
summary: God declares Himself the Almighty and reveals the creation of heaven and earth through His Only Begotten. Over six days, He brings order: light is created and separated from darkness; the firmament divides the waters; seas and dry land appear, followed by vegetation. He establishes lights in the heavens for signs and seasons; fills sea and sky with living creatures and blesses them to multiply; and forms land animals. God then says to His Only Begotten, “Let us make man in our image,” creating male and female in that image, entrusting them with dominion and the charge to be fruitful and replenish the earth. Provision is made of seed-bearing plants for humans and green herbs for animals. God sees all He has made as very good at the close of the sixth day.
externalContext: Moses is a book in the Pearl of Great Price, a Latter-day Saint scriptural volume compiled in the 19th century; this chapter parallels Genesis 1 but in a first-person divine voice revealed through Joseph Smith’s Bible translation project (1830–31). The repeated phrase “by mine Only Begotten” reflects Latter-day Saint Christology identifying the Only Begotten as Jesus Christ. The depiction of a “firmament” dividing “waters” reflects ancient Near Eastern cosmological language describing an ordered cosmos. The seventh day of rest, present in Genesis 2:2–3, appears in the next chapter (Moses 3:1–3).
externalReferences: This chapter closely parallels Genesis 1:1–31, following the same six-day structure and recurring declarations of goodness. Its statement that creation occurs “by mine Only Begotten” resonates with New Testament claims that creation came through the divine Word/Christ (John 1:1–3; Colossians 1:16). The human vocation of dominion echoes Psalm 8:4–8, which celebrates humanity’s God-given rule over creation. The sanctification of the seventh day is taken up in the subsequent narrative (Genesis 2:2–3; Moses 3:1–3).
practicalQuestions: How does viewing every person as made in God’s image change how I speak to and act toward them?
What does responsible dominion look like in my treatment of animals, resources, and the environment?
Where do I see order and purpose in the rhythms of time (signs, seasons, days, years), and how can I align my life with them for worship and service?
How does the declaration that creation is “very good” shape my attitude toward the material world and my daily work?
What might it mean for me to participate with God in creative, life-giving work that blesses others?
uncertainAreas: The precise meaning of the “firmament” and the “waters above” is unclear and may reflect ancient cosmology. The length and nature of the “days” (literal periods or symbolic epochs) is unstated. The phrase “clean herb” given for animal food and the scope of a vegetarian ideal are not fully explained. The identity of the “Only Begotten” is not explicitly defined within the chapter, though tradition links this to Christ. The nuance of “replenish the earth” (whether simply fill or refill) is not specified.
